abstracts.cdata!:
Overall, the assessment of the project
            was highly unsatisfactory. Various reasons contributed to
            negative results, among them, prudential banking regulations
            were strengthened only in theory, since timely enforcement
            did not occur. Similarly, the curbing of economic
            concentration between the state commercial banks, and a
            number of industrial group borrowers, did not occur, failing
            to accomplish significant improvements in resource
            allocation efficiency. The key lessons suggest, the project
            was an overly ambitious operation, with both unsatisfactory
            implementation and supervision. Furthermore, fundamental
            design flaws led to unrealistic expectations on banks to be
            re-capitalized, with no adequate nor aggressive
            restructuring requirements. Despite the change from an
            adjustment operation, to a "line of credit", the
            adjustment was slow. Hence, the initial quick-disbursing
            operation, implicitly conveyed, that significant supervision
            efforts would not be required, thus minimizing effective
            supervision. In addition, the lack of political will, to
            prod state bank privatization, and, achieve adequate capital
            levels, among other factors, hindered success. Complex
            financial operations, particularly involving institutional
            development, require experienced professional skills for
            both design and monitoring, which coupled with staff
            turnover, weakened the supervision effectiveness.
